summary: A New York Times article reporting the suicide death of Jeffrey Epstein in his Manhattan jail cell on August 10, 2019. It details the circumstances of his death, the ongoing investigations, his recent indictment on sex trafficking charges, and the broader context of his wealth, connections, and the 2008 plea deal.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the article; found dead by suicide in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center while awaiting trial on federal sex trafficking charges.

persons.name: William K. Rashbaum
persons.context: Co-author of the article, a senior writer covering corruption and law enforcement.

persons.name: Benjamin Weiser
persons.context: Co-author of the article, a reporter covering Manhattan federal courts.

persons.name: William P. Barr
persons.role: Attorney General of the United States
persons.context: Issued a statement expressing he was 'appalled' by Epstein's death and announced an FBI investigation and an Inspector General inquiry.

persons.name: Reid Weingarten
persons.context: Part of Epstein's defense team; issued a statement declining to comment on the cause of death.

persons.name: Marty Weinberg
persons.context: Part of Epstein's defense team; issued a statement declining to comment on the cause of death.

persons.name: Mark Epstein
persons.context: Described in a court memo as Jeffrey Epstein's 'only living immediate family member' and that the pair were close.

persons.name: Leon Black

connections.description: Wexner was Epstein's biggest client, giving him vast authority to manage his personal fortune for 16 years, which was the primary source of Epstein's wealth.
Mark is Jeffrey's younger brother and his only living immediate family member; described as close in a court memo.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead by suicide in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan at roughly 6:30 a.m.

events.title: Previous Suicide Attempt/Incident
events.description: Epstein was found unconscious in his cell with marks on his neck, investigated as a possible suicide attempt. He was placed on suicide watch afterward.

events.title: Removed from Suicide Watch
events.description: Epstein was removed from suicide watch and returned to a special housing unit.

events.title: Arrest at Teterboro Airport
events.description: Epstein was arrested at Teterboro Airport in New Jersey after his private plane landed from Paris. He was charged with sex trafficking and conspiracy.

events.title: Florida Plea Deal
events.description: Epstein avoided federal charges by pleading guilty to state charges of solicitation of prostitution from a minor, serving 13 months in jail with work release privileges.

events.title: Release of Sealed Documents
events.description: A federal appeals court released a cache of previously sealed legal documents providing new details about activities inside Epstein's homes and recruitment of victims.

locations: Private island, United States Virgin Islands
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide in his Manhattan jail cell on August 10, 2019, while awaiting trial on federal sex trafficking charges.
Epstein had been on suicide watch after a July 23 incident but was removed from that watch on July 29, just days before his death.
Attorney General William Barr announced an FBI investigation and an Inspector General inquiry into the circumstances of Epstein's death.
Much of Epstein's wealth was attributed to his management of Leslie Wexner's personal fortune, and Wexner later accused him of misappropriating 'vast sums'.
The article notes the release of a cache of sealed court documents on August 9, 2019, which provided expansive new details about Epstein's activities and the recruitment of victims.
